data.title: Christopher Reeve
data.meta_description: HE MAY technically have been an alien from another planet, but Christopher Reeve’s Superman was one of cinema’s last great traditional heroes. A man who knew right from wrong, he was a superhero
data.text:
HE MAY technically have been an alien from another planet, but Christopher Reeve’s Superman was one of cinema’s last great traditional heroes. A man who knew right from wrong, he was a superhero driven by a belief in truth and justice rather than by childhood traumas, persecution and genetic mutation.

Superman came out in 1978; it was a major hit and Reeve reprised the part in three sequels. It made him an international star overnight, but Reeve turned down other potential blockbuster roles in favour of working with the likes of Merchant Ivory on literary adaptations.

Paralysed from the neck down in a riding accident nine years ago, this most athletic of actors became a very different sort of hero, putting a human face on
